unnormalised: The Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) witnessed a flurry of activity this week, largely influenced by the RBI's decision on interest rates. Initial jitters saw the Sensex dip by 250 points in the morning session on 20/10/2024. However, market sentiment improved post-lunch, with investors showing a keen interest in the infrastructure and banking sectors.
normalised: The Bombay Stock Exchange (B-S-E) witnessed a flurry of activity this week, largely influenced by the R-B-I's decision on interest rates. Initial jitters saw the Sensex dip by two hundred and fifty points in the morning session on twentieth October two thousand and twenty four. However, market sentiment improved post-lunch, with investors showing a keen interest in the infrastructure and banking sectors.

unnormalised: Analysts are attributing the rebound to encouraging earnings reports from major IT firms. TCS shares, for instance, surged by 3% after announcing a net profit of Rs. 10,500 crore. Foreign Institutional Investors (FIIs) injected approximately $50 million into the Indian equity market, providing further impetus to the rally. Retail investors, too, are actively participating, with many channeling funds into mutual funds and SIPs.
normalised: Analysts are attributing the rebound to encouraging earnings reports from major I-T firms. T-C-S shares, for instance, surged by three percent after announcing a net profit of rupee ten thousand five hundred crore. Foreign Institutional Investors (F-I-Is) injected approximately dollar fifty million into the Indian equity market, providing further impetus to the rally. Retail investors, too, are actively participating, with many channeling funds into mutual funds and S-I-Ps.

unnormalised: Closing the week, the Nifty 50 index settled at 19,750, marking a gain of 1.2% overall. Trading volumes remained robust, averaging â‚¹75,000 crore daily. Experts advise caution, however, citing potential headwinds from global economic uncertainties and fluctuating crude oil prices (currently at $85 per barrel).
normalised: Closing the week, the Nifty fifty index settled at nineteen thousand seven hundred and fifty, marking a gain of one point two percent overall. Trading volumes remained robust, averaging rupee seventy five thousand crore daily. Experts advise caution, however, citing potential headwinds from global economic uncertainties and fluctuating crude oil prices (currently at dollar eighty five per barrel).
